regulation_detail: Pre-notification is mandatory for each expected seagoing container vessel calling at the Port of Antwerp.
Shipping agent must make the Pre-notification for a seagoing container vessel 2 months or less before arrival at entry point.
A Berth Request is mandatory for each seagoing container vessel calling at Antwerp.
Shipping agent must submit the Berth Request for a seagoing container vessel after pre-notification, no later than 24 hours before ETA Pilot vessel or ETA Entry Point (transit vessels).

Shipping agent must specify in the First Berth Request for a seagoing container vessel: ETA Entry point, Berth, Entry point, ETD, Mooring side, Operational fore/aft draught (m), Origin/Destination, Crew, Previous/Next port, Contact person details, ETD Previous port, ETA Next port, Arrival type (ETA, GTO, GTA, BTV), Comments section.

Shipping agent must send in the Specification of Arrival for a seagoing container vessel: Pilotage order, Bow/stern thruster operational status, Arrival type (updated GTO/GTA), Preferred river tugboat company, Dock services ordering (optional).
Notification of departure is required for all seagoing vessels before leaving the berth.
Masters of seagoing vessels, including container vessels, must provide prior notification of waste 24 hours before arrival.
Shipping agents for seagoing vessels, including container vessels, must submit the Waste Notification electronically via APICS desk.
Seagoing vessels calling at Port of Antwerp, including container vessels, must deposit waste at a port reception facility before leaving.
Both bunker suppliers and bunker ships must have a permit to conduct bunkering operations at the port.
Both bunker suppliers and bunker ships must have a permit to conduct bunkering operations at the port.

LNG Bunker suppliers must have a Harbour Master license for LNG delivery at Port of Antwerp, issued after positive evaluation of Bunker/Safety Procedures and other requirements. Potential service provider invited for intake interview by Harbour Master.
Bunker checklist must be fully/truthfully completed/signed by all parties for every bunkering operation.
Bunker notification via APICS (web page or API) is required for every bunkering operation.
Authorization is required from Harbour Master's Office for each LNG bunkering operation.
Declarations to Harbour Master's Office via APICS desk or EDI are mandatory for hazardous and/or polluting goods.
Declarations of hazardous and/or polluting goods to Harbour Master's Office must be submitted via APICS desk or EDI (Electronic Data Interchange).

Hazardous Goods Declarations must include specific data elements, including declarant capacity, principal mode of transport, and goods-related details (packaging, weight, UN number, IMDG class, etc.).

Transit storage facilities handling hazardous goods must have one of SDS, BIG, ERICARDS, KNAP documents available for Harbour Master's Office submission on request. Other storage facilities must have SDS available for all hazardous substances.
Maximum storage period for packaged hazardous goods in front quay transit warehouses is 30 days, non-extendable, except for specific goods with special conditions.
Companies performing fumigations in the port area must be recognized by the Harbour Master's Office.
Authorization from the Harbour Master's Office is required for fumigation operations on board ships in the port.

Fumigation of goods in warehouses, open air, fumigation zones must be reported to Harbour Master's Office by fumigation manager using HKD46 or HKD47 form, at least 24 hours before work (excluding weekends/holidays).
Pilot assistance is mandatory for seagoing vessels in non-tidal port areas of Antwerp (with specific exceptions).
Masters must always report tug requests to authorized provider via HMO IT system/communication channel.
Tug use is mandatory for pontoons with tonnage certificate or width ≥ 16m in the Port of Antwerp.
For import of containerized cargo into Port of Antwerp, an Import Customs Declaration is implicitly required to comply with EU customs regulations and Belgian customs procedures.
A Commercial Invoice is a standard supporting document typically required for customs clearance of containerized cargo at the Port of Antwerp, providing details of the transaction and cargo value.
A Packing List is a standard supporting document typically required for customs clearance of containerized cargo at the Port of Antwerp, detailing the contents of each package within the shipment.

A Bill of Lading (B/L) is a standard transport document and document of title typically required for customs clearance of imported containerized cargo at the Port of Antwerp, evidencing the contract of carriage and ownership of goods.
Shipping agents for seagoing container vessels must use the APICS system to submit the Arrival Pre-notification.
Shipping agents for seagoing container vessels must use the APICS system to submit the First Berth Request.
Bunker companies must use the APICS system to submit Conventional Bunker Notifications.
The APICS system automatically generates a unique 'stay number' upon successful submission of a Pre-notification for a seagoing vessel.
For Hazardous Goods Declarations, declarants can use EDI (Electronic Data Interchange) as an alternative to the APICS desk for electronic submission.

Shipping agents for seagoing container vessels must include the following information in the Arrival Pre-notification: (While the Port Instructions detail Berth Request info extensively, specific data for *Pre-Notification* is not explicitly listed in a clear checklist format in the analyzed sections. Further document review might be needed, or we can infer that Pre-Notification is a simpler, initial notification *before* the detailed Berth Request).

Tug use is mandatory for seagoing vessels, including container vessels, in specific docks: Southern Inlet Dock (all seagoing vessels), Inlet Dock 1 (Jetty 625A - all seagoing vessels), Bevrijdings Dock (vessels > 45m width or over 180m/250m for certain maneuvers).
Pilot assistance is mandatory for seagoing vessels, including large container vessels, at all times if visibility is less than 1000m OR wind force is ≥ 6 Beaufort (HMO assesses/communicates).

relevant_entity: Packaged Hazardous Goods in Front Quay Transit Warehouse
regulation_detail: Maximum storage period for *packaged* hazardous goods in front quay transit warehouses at Port of Antwerp is 30 days, non-extendable, except for specific goods with special conditions.

relevant_entity: General Goods (Non-Hazardous) in Transit Warehouse (Non-Front Quay)
regulation_detail: Maximum storage period for goods in transit warehouses *not located on the front quay* at Port of Antwerp is 6 months (if allowed by environmental permit).

Generally, the importer of record is responsible for ensuring customs clearance procedures are completed and all required documentation is submitted to customs authorities for containerized goods imported through the Port of Antwerp.

Containerized goods imported through the Port of Antwerp are subject to potential customs inspections, which can lead to delays if documentation is incomplete, inaccurate, or if the cargo is flagged for further scrutiny.

relevant_entity: Containerized Hazardous Goods Shipment (IMDG Class X)
regulation_detail: A Hazardous Goods Declaration is mandatory *before* a container vessel carrying hazardous goods (IMDG Class X) can fully enter the Port of Antwerp, enabling the Harbour Master's Office to assess risks and ensure safe port entry.

relevant_entity: Containerized Hazardous Goods Shipment (IMDG Class X)
regulation_detail: Safety Data Sheets (SDS) must be readily available for all containerized hazardous goods (IMDG Class X) *before handling and storage* can commence at Port of Antwerp terminals, ensuring safety information is accessible to port personnel and emergency services.
A key mechanism for Port of Antwerp to ensure environmental compliance regarding waste from seagoing vessels is the mandatory deposit of waste at port reception facilities before departure.
Port of Antwerp promotes pollution prevention during cargo handling operations by mandating scupper plugging on tankers and tank barges handling hazardous/polluting goods.
Violations of Port of Antwerp regulations are generally punished per the Decree of the Harbourmaster’s Office of 3 May 2019, without prejudice to Port Authority civil recourse for damage.

For Category 1 violations (purely administrative obligations) and Category 2 violations (ignoring HMO explicit order) of Port of Antwerp regulations, immediate collection fines are proposed (Flemish Government-determined amount).

By using APICS for Bunker Notifications, bunker companies can streamline the notification process, improve communication with the Harbour Master's Office, and contribute to more efficient bunkering operations at the Port of Antwerp.

EDI (Electronic Data Interchange) provides a more efficient alternative to the APICS desk for declarants to submit Hazardous Goods Declarations, enabling automated data exchange and potentially reducing manual processing and errors.

relevant_entity: Port Users & Port Authority (General Benefit of APICS)
regulation_detail: The 'stay number' generated by APICS upon Pre-Notification acts as a central identifier, linking various subsequent port processes and data submissions (hazardous goods notification, customs, pilotage), contributing to a more streamlined and efficient information flow for all parties involved.

A key safety regulation at Port of Antwerp mandates that all scuppers on tankers and tank barges (except gas tankers with spindle edges) must be plugged before loading/unloading hazardous/polluting goods to prevent pollution.

In the event of an oil spill at the Port of Antwerp, the Port Authority Supervisor serves as the central notification point, and port users witnessing or causing a spill must immediately report it to this point (contact details provided).

Companies operating in specific areas of the Port of Antwerp (freight handling, warehouses, transit storage, carrier sites) are required to have and submit an internal emergency response plan to the Harbour Master's Office.

Main concessionaires/owners of waterfront companies and container terminal facilities at the Port of Antwerp must take measures to prevent unauthorized access to their sites, in line with ISPS regulations, including closing off sites and implementing access control procedures.
Vessels, including container vessels, at the Port of Antwerp must ensure that no unauthorized persons can access concessions or port property via the vessel, in line with ISPS regulations.
Port of Antwerp-Bruges formed in Feb 2021 through merger, offers 'My Port of Antwerp-Bruges' digital platform for communication.
Terminal operators at Port of Antwerp-Bruges must follow notification procedures for container movements (arrival notification to customs, CODECO message).
Terminal operators must digitally report dangerous goods arrival/departure to Harbour Master's Office at Port of Antwerp-Bruges (COARRI, CODECO).
Larger vessels at Port of Antwerp-Bruges (criteria unclear - research GNA) require written permit from GNA 6 hours before pilot station arrival.
Verified Gross Mass (VGM) of packed containers must be submitted at least 24 hours before vessel's physical closing at Port of Antwerp-Bruges.
Registration on NxtPort platform is often necessary to access port applications at Port of Antwerp-Bruges.
Mandatory 'Certified Pick up' (CPu) system for secure container collection at Port of Antwerp-Bruges, replacing PIN codes. Registration required. Pickup requires 'green lights' on CPu.
Federal Public Service (FPS) Finances - Customs and Excise Administration oversees Belgian customs regulations for Port of Antwerp-Bruges.
Trader at exit must electronically notify Belgian customs of export container consignment arrival at Port of Antwerp-Bruges via CODECO message.
Empty shippers' own containers discharging in Antwerp-Bruges must be reported on import customs manifest. >100kg require full customs clearance.
Belgian customs introduced new TARIC document codes for Single Administrative Document (SAD) to comply with EU regulations.
